quiz.title: Chemistry Grade 12: Unit 4 Quiz 3
quiz.subtitle: 4.3: $\text{S}_{\text{N}}1$ Mechanism
quiz.subject: Chemistry
quiz.topic: Unimolecular nucleophilic substitution kinetics and steps

questions.question: What does the '1' in the term $\text{S}_{\text{N}}1$ stand for?
options: Unimolecular: only one molecule is involved in the rate-determining step
One-step: the reaction happens in a single concerted step
Primary: the reaction only happens on primary haloalkanes
First-order: the reaction rate depends only on the concentration of the nucleophile
questions.explanation: $\text{S}_{\text{N}}1$ stands for Substitution Nucleophilic Unimolecular. The rate-determining step involves only the dissociation of the substrate.

questions.question: What is the first and slowest step of the $\text{S}_{\text{N}}1$ mechanism?
options: Ionization of the haloalkane to form a carbocation and a halide ion
Attack of the nucleophile on the carbon atom
Formation of a transition state with five bonds
questions.explanation: The rate-limiting step is the breaking of the C-X bond to form a carbocation intermediate.

questions.question: Which of the following haloalkanes is most likely to react via an $\text{S}_{\text{N}}1$ mechanism?
questions.explanation: $\text{S}_{\text{N}}1$ reactions depend on carbocation stability. Tertiary carbocations are the most stable, making tertiary halides the most reactive in $\text{S}_{\text{N}}1$.

questions.question: The rate law for an $\text{S}_{\text{N}}1$ reaction is expressed as:
questions.explanation: Since only the substrate is involved in the slow step, the concentration of the nucleophile does not affect the initial reaction rate.

questions.question: What is the geometry of the carbocation intermediate in an $\text{S}_{\text{N}}1$ reaction?
questions.explanation: The carbocation carbon is $sp^{2}$ hybridized, resulting in a flat, trigonal planar shape with an empty $p$ orbital.

questions.question: If a chiral haloalkane reacts via an $\text{S}_{\text{N}}1$ mechanism, what is the typical stereochemical outcome?
options: Racemization (a mix of inversion and retention)
The molecule becomes achiral and stays that way
questions.explanation: Because the carbocation intermediate is planar, the nucleophile can attack from either side with nearly equal probability, leading to a racemic mixture.

questions.question: Which type of solvent best facilitates an $\text{S}_{\text{N}}1$ reaction?
questions.explanation: Polar protic solvents stabilize both the forming carbocation and the leaving halide ion through solvation (hydrogen bonding), lowering the activation energy.

questions.question: In an $\text{S}_{\text{N}}1$ reaction, what happens to the rate if the concentration of the nucleophile is doubled?
questions.explanation: The nucleophile is not involved in the rate-determining step, so changing its concentration has no effect on the rate.

questions.question: Which of the following leaving groups would result in the fastest $\text{S}_{\text{N}}1$ reaction?
questions.explanation: Iodide is the best leaving group because the C-I bond is the weakest and the larger iodide ion is better at stabilizing the negative charge.

questions.question: Which of these energy profile features is characteristic of an $\text{S}_{\text{N}}1$ reaction?
options: Two peaks (transition states) with a valley (intermediate) in between
A single peak representing a concerted step
A flat line indicating no energy change
A single transition state with five half-bonds
questions.explanation: $\text{S}_{\text{N}}1$ is a two-step mechanism. Each step has its own transition state, separated by the formation of the carbocation intermediate.

scoreMessages.90: Brilliant! You've mastered the unimolecular substitution pathway.
scoreMessages.70: Great job. You understand carbocation stability and $\text{S}_{\text{N}}1$ kinetics.
scoreMessages.50: Good progress. Remember that $\text{S}_{\text{N}}1$ is all about the 'waiting' for the leaving group to leave.
scoreMessages.0: Review the two-step nature of $\text{S}_{\text{N}}1$ and why $3^{\circ}$ halides prefer it.
